title: 109_hr6308
content: The Act is titled the "Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System Act of 2006" and includes definitions for various terms used within the Act. The Act defines key terms such as Authority, Plan, Secretary, State, and System, which refers to the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System delivering water to several cities. The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System serves cities in Curry and Roosevelt Counties, including Clovis, Elida, Grady, Melrose, Portales, and Texico. It includes an intake structure, water treatment facility, pipelines, and pumping stations. The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System includes a raw water pump station at Ute Reservoir, a booster pump station at the "Caprock" escarpment, a booster pump station to Elida, and any associated appurtenances. Ute Reservoir is the impoundment of water created in 1962 by the construction of the Ute Dam on the Canadian River. The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System includes infrastructure such as raw water pump stations, booster pump stations, and associated appurtenances. The Secretary may provide financial and technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, and constructing the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System. The financial assistance must be used in accordance with a cooperative agreement and cannot be used for activities inconsistent with the System or for irrigation water facilities. The Federal share of the total cost of the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System shall not exceed 75 percent. No funds from this Act can be used for construction until a plan is developed and environmental requirements are met. Title to the infrastructure of the System will be held by the Authority or as specified under State law. The Authority is responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs of the System. They will develop a plan with the Secretary to establish rates and fees for beneficiaries to ensure proper maintenance and water delivery. Administrative provisions are also outlined. The Secretary may enter into contracts, grants, or agreements to carry out the Act, including a cooperative agreement with the Authority for financial assistance in planning, design, and construction of the System. The agreement specifies responsibilities for cost-sharing. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, constructing, and operating the System. The Secretary shall consult with relevant entities for preparing any biological assessment under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Act does not affect State water law or interstate compacts related to water allocation, nor does it grant non-Federal entities Federal water rights. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary to carry out the Act, with nonreimbursable amounts and availability of unexpended funds for future fiscal years.
